prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(J=4-3) for WISE J102905.90+050132.4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will observe 12CO (J=4-3) for WISE J1029+0501 (z = 0.493) by using band-7 with a beam size of 0.15 arcsec. We will use 1 spectral window for CO line observation and other 3 spectral windows for continuum observations. Estimated total time for science goal is 1.46 hr to achieve the S/N = 10.5 for observed line, according to the OT.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The peak line flux density [mJy/beam] for 12CO (J=4-3) was estimated as follows: 1. We estimated the total infrared luminosity (L_IR) from an empirical relation between 22 ?m luminosity and L_IR for DOGs provided in Melbourne et al. (2012). 2. We estimated the 12CO (J=1-0) luminosity (L_CO) using a typical luminosity ratio, i.e., (L_IR / L_C0) = 170 for ULIRGs descried in Gao & Solomon 2004b (ApJS 606 270), where the L_CO is given in unit of [K km s^-1 pc^2]. 3. We converted L_CO in unit of [K km s^-1 pc^2] to flux (S_CO) [mJy km s^-1] using Eq.(3) in Solomon & Vanden Bout 2005 (ARA&A, 43, 677). 4. We estimated the line flux for 12CO (J=4-3) by multiplying S_CO by 8. We note that if the targeted gas is thermalized, we can multiply S_CO by 4^2 = 16, but it is unclear whether or not it is completely thermalized. So, we conservatively multiplied S_CO by 16 /2 = 8. 5. We estimated S_CO (J=4-3) [mJy km s^-1 beam^-1] by assuming the size of emission region and the beam size (i.e., the expected angular resolution). In this case, we adopted 0.15 arcsec as the beam size. 6. We estimated the expected peak sensitivity [mJy/beam] by assuming the gaussian profile with FWHM = 50 [km/s].
As a result, the peak flux density is 15.68 mJy/beam. When the requested RMS (1.50 mJy) will be realized, the S/N will reach 10.5, which ensures the line detection is sufficiently detected.
-------- We estimated the continuum flux by performing the SED fitting for our target where we utilized the SED template provided in Narayanan et al. 2010 (MNRAS, 407, 1701), and estimated the continuum. Note that the total infrared luminosity obtained from the result of SED fitting is consistent with that obtained from an empirical relation given in Melbourne et al. 2012 (AJ, 143, 125). The continuum continuum flux is 22 mJy and achieved S/N will be 553.9, which is sufficiently high for our science.
-------- We adopted 5.0 km/s as a bandwidth, which means that detected emission line can be represented using over 2 ? (50.0 / 5.0) = 20 bins. Since we will not investigate the detailed shape of the emission line, this bandwidth is suitable.
We assumed 50 km/s as line width (50 km/s) in reference to the results obtained from ALMA observations (e.g., Garcia-Burillo et al. 2014 (A&A, 567,125) and Espada et al. 2012 (ApJ, 760 ,25)).

The requested angular resolution (0.15 arcsec) enables us to resolve ~900 pc for the target, which cannot resolve each molecular cloud but the bulk of molecular clouds can be traced. This observation with ALMA will give us the overall trend in terms of the spatial and velocity structure for the first time in the dusty population.
The largest angular scale (2.44) arcsec) was instead from the optical image taken by the SDSS. We used the Petrosian (1976, ApJ, 209, 1) radius. When the distribution of the surface brightness is same, this radius is same regardless of their redshift, which is useful especially for high-z (z > 0.3) objects.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(J=2-1) for WISE J102905.90+050132.4

We will use 1 spectral window for CO line observation and other 3 spectral windows for continuum observations. Estimated total time for science goal is 1.64 hr to achieve the S/N = 9.8 for observed line, according to the OT.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The peak line flux density [mJy/beam] for 12CO (J=2-1) was estimated as follows: 1. We estimated the total infrared luminosity (L_IR) from an empirical relation between 22 ?m luminosity and L_IR for DOGs provided in Melb ourne et al. (2012). 2. We estimated the line flux for 12CO (J=2-1) by multiplying S_CO by 4, where we assumed that the targeted gas is thermalized. 5. We estimated S_CO (J=2-1) [mJy km s^-1 beam^-1] by assuming the size of emission region and the beam size (i.e., the expected angular resolution). In this case, we adopted 0.15 arcsec as the beam size. 6. We estimated the expected peak sensitivity [mJy/beam] by assuming the gaussian profile with FWHM = 50 [km/s].
As a result, the peak flux density is 7.84 mJy/beam. When the requested RMS (0.08 mJy) will be realized, the S/N will reach 9.8, which ensures the line detection is sufficiently detected.

Note that the total infrared luminosity obtained from the result of SED fitting is consistent with that obtained from an empirical relation given in Melbourne et al. 2012 (AJ, 143, 125). This observation with ALMA will give us the overall trend in terms of the spatial and velocity structure for the first time in the dusty population.

When the distribution of the surface brightness is same, this radius is same regardless of their redshift, which is useful especially for high-z (z > 0.3) objects.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The peak line flux density [mJy/beam] for 12CO (J=2-1) was estimated as follows: 1. We estimated the total infrared luminosity (L_IR) from an empirical relation between 22 ?m luminosity and L_IR for DOGs provided in Melb ourne et al. (2012). 2. We estimated the 12CO (J=1-0) luminosity (L_CO) using a typical luminosity ratio, i.e., (L_IR / L_C0) = 170 for ULIRGs descried in Gao & Solomon 2004b (ApJS 606 270), where the L_CO is given in unit of [K km s^-1 pc^2]. 3. We estimated S_CO (J=2-1) [mJy km s^-1 beam^-1] by assuming the size of emission region and the beam size (i.e., the expected angular resolution). In this case, we adopted 0.15 arcsec as the beam size. 6. We estimated the expected peak sensitivity [mJy/beam] by assuming the gaussian profile with FWHM = 50 [km/s].

Note that the total infrared luminosity obtained from the result of SED fitting is consistent with that obtained from an empirical relation given in Melbourne et al. 2012 (AJ, 143, 125). This observation with ALMA will give us the overall trend in terms of the spatial and velocity structure for the first time in the dusty population.

When the distribution of the surface brightness is same, this radius is same regardless of their redshift, which is useful especially for high-z (z > 0.3) objects.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We aim to reveal the relation between the SF activity and the molecular gas outflow regarding the AGN positive/negative feedback, in the extremely IR-bright Dust Obscured Galaxies (DOGs) through the observations of 12CO (J=4--3), 12CO (J=2--1) as well as continuum observations.
The extremely IR-bright DOGs are a key population to understand the growing phase of the co-evolution between galaxies and supermassive black holes. Investigating how the molecular gas outflow affects the SF activity in the IR-bright DOGs is crucial to tackle the mystery of the co-evolution behind the dust.
Combining the latest SDSS data with WISE data, we discovered 65 extremely IR-bright DOGs over the largest survey footprint so far. Among them, we discovered four peculiar objects that show a clear outflow associated with ionized gasses ([OIII]) outflow in their optical spectra, although whether or not the neutral molecular gasses are also associated with outflow. For them, we will investigate the spatial distribution and of dense and diffuse molecular gas as well as velocity distribution. In addition, we will investigate their SFR map derived from far-IR luminosity based on continuum data.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Liberal Arts, Kogakuin University
The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
